column4: hi I just installed ubuntu on another computer but the network isnt working
I tried everything I know but cant get it to work
anyone?

You do not give much to go on. Do your system have two (or more) network cards?
: It has 2 network cards one is onboard but disabled in the bios and the other is in  pci card
in a CLI try "dmesg | fgrep eth0" should show if Ubuntu sees the HW
Pharaoh_Atem> ok I have to run back over to that pc to try it
Pharaoh_Atem: I am not familar with the name it gave me, but it dint have the cnet pro name in it
How do you give IP to your system? (DHCP?)
The quick and ugly test would be to switch the cable to the other card and try again.
the onboard one isnt working ... the light on the switch didnt even come on
any idea what to do next here?
The other card is turned of then. Well try: "dmesg | fgrep -i eth". Should show if your system is seing any eth card. No idea, not realy.
Thanks for nothing more likely. :-( Well your best shot would be to see if Ubuntu sees any NICs. And start from there.
Does it get eth0 or eth1 as its name.
What does "cat /etc/network/interfaces" tell you

I just enabled the onboard nic ... the light on the switch comes on now. "cat /etc/network/interfaces" tells me all but eth0 are dhcp while eth0 is static, address 192.168.254.1, subnet mask 255.255.255.0, gateway 192.168.254.254 (which is the ip of my router)
Can you ping from the machine, your router as an example. Yeah I agree. dmesg should give you a hint on which cards are alive and which not.

Then its truly dead. Can the system ping itself on the 192... address? You could always conf eth0 on one address, and then eth1 on another and try em out. But now Im grasping. Truly dont have a clue anymore.

To setup a network: 1) Check link (the green led on card and router/switch - HW ok) 2) System can "ping 127.0.0.1" (Kernel agrees, we have network). 3) "ifconfig" to verify cards and setup (I changed config. and the kernel accepted it) 4) Ping system on its real address (routs are more or less right). 5) "route -n" to verify that default route is sane (we might have access to the big word). 6) ping default gateway (route actually work
Obviously you have to manually verify output from "ifconfig" and "route". But should be fairly easy to understand their output.
